job_title: Anonymous Employee in Walla Walla, WA
pros: Though the college doesn't pay especially well on a national scale, salaries are okay in the local small-town economy, and the benefits are generous. The campus is lovely and there are always performances and cultural experiences available. Many staff members gladly stay at Whitman for decades. If you're a people person, you'll find opportunities to build lasting friendships and working relationships.
cons:
The faculty are sacred cows: it can take only a single faculty complaint to derail a project or to ignore best practices. 

The workplace-as-family environment means that business decisions are usually made by consensus or by arbitrary management fiat, not on the basis of outcomes and processes.

It's a 150-year-old institution staffed by lifers, not an organization that can prioritize effectiveness. If you're used to life in the for-profit world, then this environment may be really demotivating.

review_title: Civilized small-town living (if you like that sort of thing)
job_title: Office Assistant in Walla Walla, WA
pros: I was in an office admin position at Whitman, so my experience is with staff relations and not faculty, with whom I did not have a whole lot of professional contact.  My department did not have too much in the way of office politics, bickering, or infighting.  People tended to stay for a long time.
cons: One definitely overheard the usual stories of professors sleeping with their students, and endured a certain amount of meetings over budgets and the other sort of bureaucratic roadblocks that one expects in higher education administration.  Staff and faculty did not seem to interact much at all when I was there, but that may have changed.

review_title: Where does all that money go?
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Walla Walla, WA
pros: Working at Whitman provided me with an invaluable practical education into how the American higher education racket really works.
cons:
As for my own experience as an employee, these things come to mind:

(1) Management -- my own and those around me -- did not seem to grasp the basics; for example, it was repeatedly made clear to me that managers did not know the FLSA status of their subordinates, and were unaware of changes in FLSA law in the past ten years.

(2) Interviews - Extraordinary resources were expended on ordinary job interviews. Dozens of people were involved and whole departments participated in group q&a sessions for relatively low-level positions. And did this extravagant expenditure of human resources  yield outstanding results? I don't think so. I suspect that many candidates went away feeling they were not treated with respect and having a lower general option of Whitman College.

job_title: Communications Photographer in Walla Walla, WA
pros: The communications office gives great advice and feedback on photo and video work. The office trusts that you will do great work.
cons: As a communications photographer, you are mainly working within the campus and with other students so there is not as much immediate experience with outside professional workplaces, although,you are the freedom and resources to work with outside people if you seek out those opportunities.

job_title: Math & Computer Science Technical and Instructional Aide in Walla Walla, WA
pros: Good community, good work, decent pay. I worked as a part-time tutor for computer science there and I had a good time. Lots of engagement from my supervisor.
cons: The only real cons I can say is that there was a lack of adequate training for the lab aides.

review_title: One of the better places to work in Walla Walla.

review_title: A big commitment for students with good training and access to college leadership
